# News comment title:
Chart of the Day: Net New Jobs in November

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
"It won't help things, but I doubt that it will hurt much either."


Well, "things" are complicated.  At least in the near term, a small rise in the interest rate, at the same time Europeans are dealing with a weak economy at home, will probably strengthen the dollar.  This, in turn, will increase the purchasing power of American consumers, while simultaneously reducing American exports and worsening the trade deficit.


So the folks who are helped will have something of an overlap with the folks who are hurt.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
*sigh*  Another month, another epic Obama FAIL.  I miss the golden age of Bush-Era prosperity.  His last month in office alone saw an epic 818k jobs*.  Obama has yet to even come close to that!

* note:  in order to arrive at that number, you have to take the official jobs number from bls.gov and "unskew" it by invoking the law of inverse negativity.  Unskewed data makes everything better, because reasons, patriotism, and possibly (Supply Side) Jesus.
/snark

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


There goes that Kenyan Colonialist Socialist killing the economy yet again!

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Your task is to analyze the news comment and determine its stances towards specific targets. ### Context ### Comment posted on date: 2016-03-04 18:23:52 # News comment title: Chart of the Day: Net New Jobs in February # Oldest comment (from the thread): someone who now has a job but who did not previously have one has experienced infinite wage growth. # Most liked comment (from the thread): Well, hang on. Wages and employment are countervailing forces, which can work together to power a "virtuous cycle" or a vicious one, but the nature of spiral movement is that such forces work alternately rather than simultaneously. Simple supply-and-demand economics says that employment growth will slacken while wages rise, and wages will plateau while there is a surge in employment. When wages rise, a new tranche of labor becomes available, and it takes a while for employers to "soak it up." I think it was instinctive.  Trump has one hell of an instinct for who's got strength and who doesn't. Regardless of what Wilbur Ross thinks, it is unlikely that Paul Ryan or Mitch McConnell will let a 5% tariff go through.  They claim to favor free trade, and much of their donations come from the business community that benefits from this free trade.

Many regulations designed to protect consumers and the environment will affect working class people the most if they are rolled back as expected.  Expected oil spikes will bring back inflationary cycles which also hurt working class the most as wages always lag behind rising prices.  And ultimately we are looking at a recession with Trump as interest rates rise precipitously to slow inflation, putting a lot of people out of work, most of which will be working class.

This makes no sense. When the economy is expanding, the economy needs the money supply to grow so that the demand for more transactions can be satisfied. Credit expansion can do this over the short term, but that's inherently time limited as private sector balance sheets become more leveraged. Federal deficit spending has no such time constraint. When you realize that "national debt" is just another way of saying "the money supply", the idea of reducing it when inflation is low becomes obviously stupid. Edit: Also, we're running a trade deficit, which means that we're essentially exporting dollars. If the federal deficit is smaller than the trade deficit then the dollars we're exporting are coming from the private sector, which either reduces the number of domestic transactions that can be accomodated, or simply time shifts this reduction in activity via private sector credit expansion. # Most liked comment (from the thread): US solar power employs more people than oil, coal and gas combined, report shows, http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-solar-power-employs-more-people-more-oil-coal-gas-combined-donald-trump-green-energy-fossil-fuels-a7541971.html
Solar energy in the US employs more people than traditional coal, gas and oil combined, a report has found, in a revelation that could undermine Donald Trump’s argument that green energy isn’t good for the economy. . . . Solar energy employed 374,000 people over the year 2015-2016, making up 43 per cent of the sector’s workforce, while the traditional fossil fuels combined employed 187,117, making up just 22 per cent of the workforce, according to the report. “Proportionally, solar employment accounts for the largest share of workers in the Electric Power Generation sector. This is largely due to the construction related to the significant build out of new solar generation capacity,” the report states. It adds that this gap is growing, with net generation from coal sources declining by 53 per cent between 2006 and September 2016, while electricity generation from natural gas increased by 33 per cent and solar by over 5,000 per cent in the same period. In the past year alone, solar industry employment has increased by 25 per cent, adding 73,000 new jobs to the economy, while wind energy employment saw an even larger increase of 32 per cent. Data in the report shows the overall number of jobs in energy efficiency increased by 133,000 to a total of 2.2 million within that year. According to the report, 6.4 million Americans now work in the energy industry and 2016 added 300,000 new net jobs, which made up 14 per cent of the entire job growth of the US for that year. . . . .

# News comment title:
Chart of the Day: The Cost of an ER Visit Is Skyrocketing

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Certainly technology plays into this. If you want to be State-of-the-art (and who doesn’t in ER?), you must have the latest.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
A few factoids fwiw:
-- ERs are profit centers for hospitals.  ER charges offset many of the losses hospitals incur from, e.g., treating patients who can't pay.
-- "Retail" prices for hospital services -- ANY hospital services -- bear only some relation to the actual costs of providing those services.  This is true of medical prices generally, of course -- look at your next insurance benefits statement, and compare the "charges" to the amounts paid -- but it is especially true for hospital charges.
-- The US has WAY too many hospitals.  Compare our distribution even to western Europe's, much less that of any other region.  As a result, they are engaged in terrible market competition, winnowing out, merging and consolidation, etc.  This exacerbates the two trends described above.  And it's made worse by "critical care centers" and other "quasi-hospitals," who skim off the people who just need an antacid or an antibiotic, and send the serious medical problems to the real hospitals.
-- Net result of all the above: "retail" ER charges are going through the roof.  $50 aspirins.  $75 bandages.  $500 for a brief MD consult.  "Facility" charges as noted.  And that's not counting what happens if you REALLY need help.

Fortunately, Donald Trump will fix all this.  Only he can do so.  We are saved, just in time!

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

# News comment title:
Do Republicans Believe Their Own Lies?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
If it was just that, I'd say they were, but ask yourself what haven't they willing to lie about? Do you really think they believe their tax plan is good for the middle class? Where have they shown any integrity? No, they don't believe their lies, and neither do the alt-right or most of the trolls here - they know they are dishonest, but they will go along with anything they think will benefit them.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
As far as Republican politicians and spokespeople go, they know what their talking points are and have them memorized, and the issue of whether or not what they are saying is true is probably not even something they concern themselves with. I doubt most of them even know or care whether they are telling the truth or lying, they just want to get their side’s talking points out regardless of whether they are true or false. So asking whether they believe something or not is essentially a meaningless question as far as Republican politicians go, they do not really have “beliefs” in the first place. They just know that they are supposed to say certain things if they want to achieve political success as politicians or PR flacks in their party, and whether something is true or false is the furthest thing from their minds, something they have long ago learned to ignore. Many of them believe that if you repeat a lie enough times it becomes the truth, and have convinced themselves that if they get enough people to believe something currently untrue, it will BECOME true, so their notions of truth vs. falsehood do not follow the traditional notion of there being a single objective reality that statements by humans cannot alter.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Yes but look at the case of the vacant SC justice. Reid should have gone nuclear

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Climategate Was an Early Prototype for Russia’s Campaign Hacking in 2016

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Also fascinating, how the FBI warned the Trump campaign to report all contacts with Russia during the election and will now use the fact that they failed to notify them as further evidence of collusion.

https://www.rawstory.com/2017/12/ex-intel-agent-says-trump-team-damned-itself-by-ignoring-fbi-on-russia-were-going-to-keep-that-as-evidence/

 A former counterintelligence agent says that President Donald Trump’s former campaign team may be in deep trouble after they ignored FBI warnings that Russia would try to infiltrate the campaign.

NBC News reported on Monday that weeks after Trump became the 2016 Republican nominee for president, the FBI notified the campaign that foreign agents, including Russians, would “try to spy on and infiltrate his campaign.”

Former FBI counterintelligence agent Frank Montoya told NBC that Trump’s campaign team would have been told, “If you see these kinds of contacts please let us know about them so we can keep you updated on the threat picture.”

Although members of the Trump team had repeated contacts with Russians after the FBI warnings, officials with the campaign reportedly never notified law enforcement authorities.

“If I give you a defensive briefing and the illicit behavior continues, I’m not going to just scratch my head over that, especially if I see continued interference,” Montoya explained. “If we’re telling these guys stuff and they are not acting on it, then we’re going to keep that as evidence.”

# News comment title:
More Good News on Retirement Savings

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Would be nice if there was a label on the Y axis...  just saying... Is this percent of total income? Percent of after tax? Some abstract measure?

Clicking on the link yields a 30 page, statistics dense, PDF research report with no equivalent chart, so the one here is derived from that data, but without an explanation of what exactly is being graphed the significance is hard to gauge. (Yes, I basically know what Kevin is trying to get across, I'm a scientist with a strong background in statistics, but an unlabeled chart leaves too much to interpretation.)

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Clarification, Kevin: IRAs and 401(k)s aren't always exactly separate things: Prudent people, when they retire, typically roll their 401(s) over into IRAs. (And some still-working people might roll over plans to an IRA when they change jobs.) So what had been a 401(k) suddenly gets added to the gross amounts in IRAs the second a person rolls over the old workplace 401(k).

Also, when talking about having an IRA for retirement, whether or not a person has a traditional IRA (deposits taxed when withdrawn) or a Roth IRA (taxed at savings time) can make a big difference, according to whether the market is high or low at deposit and withdrawal times.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Nice to se younger folks saving for retirement as I didn't start until I was 30. But I'm really getting worried about folks market exposure in the 401s/IRAs. We're heading to another market bubble, perhaps sooner than later.

# News comment title:
Getting the Kids to Vote

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
"What am I missing here?"

That if "kids" haven't figured out by now that it's really, really bad to force a woman to give birth against her will, to roll back the rights of the LGBTQ community, to obstruct the voting rights of people of color, to deport 800,000 Dreamers, to lock little kids up in cages, to make health care more expensive so rich people can get tax cuts, and to contaminate the air they breathe, the water they drink and the food they eat so greedy, Planet-bashing billionaires can protect their profits.......and that they should stand up and do something about it......

.......Then there's nothing anybody can say to them at this juncture that's going to get them to the polls because they clearly don't give a shit. If they just don't care, then there's no electoral "there" there.

And they won't stay off my lawn, dammit!

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I spent an afternoon at UC Irvine doing voter registration a few weeks ago. It was a Sunday and was a total bust. Very few people on campus. But I did talk to 20-25 students. Learned some things.

1) Undergraduates are mostly clueless. They're just learning to be on their own after years of having everything done for them. They're busy learning to keep a schedule and remember to eat. If there's a homework set due the day after election day, there's a 90% chance they won't vote. Just my impressions.

2) Lots of college kids are confused about whether they can vote where they go to college. When they learn they can vote at the college address, they're not sure about changing their address. The point is: lotsa complications.

3) Graduate students are up on things and focused. Since they take pride in being opinionated and are about to launch themselves into the job market, they are politically aware and know about candidates and elections.

All of this to me adds up to: the vote yield/volunteer time with youth voter registration/canvassing ratio is really really low.

If I were running a "youth voting organization" I would

-- Focus on grad students and, along with that, getting grad students to get their siblings/younger friends to vote through some sort of app as mentioned in KD's post.

-- Have rallies with Taylor Swift types wherever possible

-- Work on passing laws that register students to vote at their current address when they register for classes, and that put voting places right on campus, in the student center.

Just to be clear: I don't know what I'm talking about. I'm just throwing out the ideas that came to mind after my 3 hours wandering around trying to register people.

Oh, another thing I'll add -- my 3 hours and my tiny sample of conversations convinced me I've underestimated how much undergraduates don't like both parties and view them both as collections of selfish, inept adults who are messing up the world for them. In other words, they don't see the profound difference between the parties I do.

# News comment title:
Three Stories for Friday Morning

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It's a key to understanding the symbiotic relationship between Trump and right-wing media. Contrary to popular belief Trump is not a particularly good liar. He seems to go out of his way to make his claims sound as outlandish as possible. But he knows how to nurture his cult, and--this is the most crucial point--he has right-wing media ready to defend and amplify every lie that comes out of his mouth.

As a contrast, think back to the way Bush justified the invasion of Iraq at one of the debates: "The enemy attacked us." He never said outright that Saddam was behind 9/11, but he was clearly trying to imply it. That's the old method of deception in politics: use careful wording to give your lies plausible deniability. If Trump had been in the same position, he would have simply declared that Saddam had personally given the call that brought down the towers. And FOX, Breitbart and all the rest would have come up with lengthy defenses of this claim.

Even back in mid-2015 when right-wing media was not totally on Trump's side since he had no power at that point (wasn't president, wasn't even the GOP nominee and was widely regarded as a long-shot if not an absurd impossibility to become either), he was largely saying things that FOX et al had been inculcating their audience with for years. Once he became the nominee, and later the president, they became committed to brainwashing their audience into accepting whatever crazy thing came out of Donald Trump's mouth. They would have done it for any GOP leader, of course; they did do it for Bush, and they would have done it for Romney or Rubio or any other Republican who happened to make it to the White House. But with Trump, they also have make sure they're not running aground of the cult. So Trump and right-wing media to some degree depend on each other.

"About 10-15 percent of teens who try marijuana become dependent. This is roughly similar to the rate for alcohol dependency." ......But a dependency is not the same as an addiction.........


"When people use the term “dependence,” they are usually referring to a physical dependence on a substance. Dependence is characterized by the symptoms of tolerance and withdrawal. While it is possible to have a physical dependence without being addicted, addiction is usually right around the corner."

"Addiction is marked by a change in behavior caused by the biochemical changes in the brain after continued substance abuse." ....... https://www.addictioncenter.com/addiction/addiction-vs-dependence/


I don't claim to be a neurologist or an addictions specialist, but I haven't seen any credible data that suggests excessive marijuana causes the same kind of changes in the brain that alcohol abuse can cause, nor are marijuana "withdrawals" as challenging as alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Am I wrong?
